results.title: Violent Cop = Sono otoko kyobo ni tsuki (D)
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Kazuyoshi Okuyama, Bandai Visual Company and Shochiku-Fuji Co
results.brief_description: Takeshi Kitano’s aptly named “Violent cop” is a sadistic and offbeat exercise in screen violence. Expected comparisons to the gleeful revenge soaked fantasies and moral righteousness of the Dirty Harry series are quickly dissipated by Kitano’s deadpan, morally ambiguous protagonist and the unexpected comic moments sandwiched between the painful and bleak depictions of violence. ‘Beat’ Takeshi plays a hardened cop whose special brand of rough justice lands him in bad favor with his supervisors. Things begin to spiral out of control when he tries to help a corrupt colleague who has become involved with the Yakuza. To make matters worse his mentally unstable sister is also lured into the gang, accumulating into the inevitable bloody showdown. In Japanese with English subtitles Cast also includes Maiko Kawakami, Makoto Ashikawa, Shigeru Hiraizumi and Shiro Sano.

results.title: Violence on the screen
results.creator_credit: Cathy Johnstone and Video Education Australia
results.brief_description: The issue about whether violence on the screen and in the media influences the behaviour of the community, especially children, is a contentious one. This program, comprising of two videos - ‘I wrote to Steven Spielberg’ and ‘Bobo dolls and copy cats’, as well as video support notes, attempts to provide a well rounded introduction to the complexities of the debate. Many questions are raised and discussed, but it should be noted that due to the complex nature of the subject, a definitive answer cannot be reached. The program discusses the difference between real, fictional and implied violence. Discusses the notion of intent, including the difficult areas of comedy and cartoon violence, as well as the impact of television news. It introduces the idea that one effect of viewing violence may be an altered perception of the amount of violence in the world. It discusses the role of Australia’s film and television classification system; asks whether violence is always bad, and asks students to consider whether children are an especially susceptible audience. It also introduces the notion that violence in the media may serve cultural, psychological or historical needs, and asks students to consider whether it’s violence in the media or other factors in people’s lives that are more important in determining actions. Suitable for middle to senior secondary school students in Media Studies, English, and related Studies of Society and Environment.

results.title: Violence in the Cinema.....Part 1
results.creator_credit: George Miller, Byron Kennedy, Warlok Films and Acta Scienta
results.brief_description: A graphic satire on the representation of violence in the cinema, this early work by George Miller has “psychologist and media critic”, Dr. Edgar Fine, providing an academic account on the various theories around this subject. What starts as a fairly didactic and dry discourse on violence in the cinema takes a turn for the gruesomely demonstrative. Brutal acts are performed in visceral detail. This short by Miller was also his first collaboration with producer Byron Kennedy, whom he met at the University of New South Wales. The success of this collaboration led them to form the production company Kennedy Miller and to embody their fascination with violence in the feature film, ‘Mad Max’ (1979).

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 9 & 10
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel 4, WGBH (Boston) and Malone Gill Productions
results.brief_description: The power of the purse recounts the rise of Bordeaux as the prime wine producing area of France in the eighteenth century. Massive investment by the nouveaux riches led to the rise of Chateaux Latour, Lafite and Margaux and others who based their success on well-drained soil and insistence on the latest and best cellar techniques. “The devastator” describes the catastrophic effect on the French wine industry of phylloxera which wiped out almost all of the vineyards. Scientific investigations by Pasteur and Planchon solved the problem and introduced new techniques to viticulture.

results.title: Winter sleepers = Winterschlafer
results.creator_credit: Tom Tykwer, Stefan Arndt, German Independents, FFA - Filmforderungsanstalt, Bavaria Film, BMI, Arte, Mitteldeutscher Rundfunk, WDR, Palladio Film, FilmFernsehFonds Bayern, Filmstiftung NRW and X filme creative Pool
results.brief_description: Tykwer’s elaborately designed second feature, which preceded his commercially successful ‘Run Lola Run’ (1998), is set in a ski village in a remote province in southern Germany. The plot follows the various threads that connect the confused lives of two couples in their thirties. Theo, a projectionist in the local theatre, steals a car belonging to lovers Rebecca and Marco and takes it for a joyride. He collides with the car of a local farmer gravely injuring his daughter, but due to a short term memory loss, leaves the scene without helping the injured girl or her family. Later he becomes involved with Laura, a nurse, who has been taking care of the girl. Both couples are rootless and without ambition or drive, and Tywker uses the time allowed by his elliptical narrative to compare and contrast the two relationships on display. He deploys stylistic formalism to make connections between what are essentially shallow characters. Their incompatibilities are underpinned by the use of colour-coding, while the repeated use of lap dissolves sets up unexpected connections between them. Cast includes Floriane Daniel, Heino Ferch, Ulrich Matthes, Marie-Lou Sellem and Josef Bierbichler. In German with English subtitles.
